title: How to Make Family Photo Magnets

steps.headline: Find digital pictures of everyone in your family.
steps.description: You can take new pictures and load them from a camera onto a computer, or you can find old pictures that are stored in Picasa, Facebook, iPhoto or another photography software's archives.

steps.headline: Purchase magnet photo paper from craft stores or online.
steps.description: This special type of photo paper is more expensive than photo paper, but it allows you to make photo magnets very quickly. Test a sheet to make sure it works in your printer.

steps.headline: Resize your image so that it fits within a portion of the magnet paper.
steps.description: For uniform sized family photo magnets, choose photos where the faces are approximately the same size.

steps.headline: Print each photo in the same dimensions on different sheets of magnet paper.
steps.description: You may be able to fit a few different photos on 1 sheet by turning the sheet and feeding it back into the printer. Allow the ink on the magnet paper to dry completely before touching it.

steps.headline: Cut the magnet paper to the size of your choice.
steps.description: Stick them on the fridge. Use your family photo magnets as a game for your infant or toddler. Place the magnets on a low appliance or safe piece of metal. Allow the child to arrange the pictures at their level. Add magnetic letters and numbers to increase the educational content of the activity.

steps.headline: Crop your photos so that they are square.
steps.description: You will be fashioning regular photographs to look like Polaroids, so you can use any digital photographs that you own. Photographs from the application Instagram are already in a square form and can be printed as is.

steps.headline: Print off the square photographs on your printer, using photo paper.
steps.description: You can also print them inexpensively at a kiosk or using an online picture printing service.

steps.headline: Aim for the photo to be approximately 3 inches by 3 inches (7.6 by 7.6 cm) - approximately the size of a standard Polaroid photo image.
steps.description: You can also cut them down to this size after they are printed.

steps.headline: Buy magnet sheets at a craft store or online.
steps.description: Look for neodymium magnet paper. This type of magnet may be more expensive than standard magnet craft sheets; however, it can hold up considerably more weight than standard models.

steps.headline: Cut the magnet sheets into sizes of 3.5 inches (8.9 cm) wide and 4.5 inches (11.4 cm) tall.
steps.description: This is approximately the size of a single Polaroid  sheet, including white space.

steps.headline: Place double stick tape on the back of your photo in 2 to 4 places.
steps.description: Make sure not to touch the tape too much before application, or it will lose its stickiness.

steps.headline: Place the photograph approximately 1/4 inch from the top and sides of the front of the magnet sheet.
steps.description: Press on the photograph to firmly attach it to the magnet sheet. You will leave extra space at the bottom for writing. If you are worried about aligning the photo correctly onto the magnet paper, practice before you affix the double stick tape. Trace around the top corners with the pencil. Align the corners again once you have tape on the back.

steps.headline: Write information about your family members on the bottom of the photo magnet.
steps.description: You can use different colored markers for more lively illustrations. Place the magnets on a metallic surface.

steps.headline: Purchase glass shapes and button magnets from a craft store.
steps.description: You will also need strong glue that dries clearly.

steps.headline: Find photographs of your family member's profiles or faces, approximately in the size of the glass craft gems.
steps.description: Most gems are round, which works well with faces. Square gems will also work.

steps.headline: Print out photographs of your family members on plain white paper.
steps.description: Adjust your printer's settings for a high quality printing.

steps.headline: Cut out the faces on the photographs, so that the image is slightly bigger than the gem.
steps.description: It will need to wrap around the back slightly.

steps.headline: Paint a coat of glue on the back of the glass gem.
steps.description: This is usually the side that is flat and less shiny.

steps.headline: Place the photograph face forward on top of the glue.
steps.description: Press it down firmly with your hand. Allow it to dry. Trim any excess paper before counting.

steps.headline: Paint a second coat of clear glue over the back of the photograph.
steps.description: This will firmly affix the edges of the paper, and it will make the magnet last longer. Allow the coat to dry according to package directions.

steps.headline: Place a dot of glue on the center of the gem.
steps.description: Press a button magnet to the middle of the back of the photograph and gem. Allow it to dry, repeat with other photographs and place on a metal surface.

text: Easy Family Photo Magnets Find digital pictures of everyone in your family. You can take new pictures and load them from a camera onto a computer, or you can find old pictures that are stored in Picasa, Facebook, iPhoto or another photography software's archives. Purchase magnet photo paper from craft stores or online. This special type of photo paper is more expensive than photo paper, but it allows you to make photo magnets very quickly. Test a sheet to make sure it works in your printer. Resize your image so that it fits within a portion of the magnet paper. For uniform sized family photo magnets, choose photos where the faces are approximately the same size. Print each photo in the same dimensions on different sheets of magnet paper. You may be able to fit a few different photos on 1 sheet by turning the sheet and feeding it back into the printer. Allow the ink on the magnet paper to dry completely before touching it. Cut the magnet paper to the size of your choice. Stick them on the fridge. Use your family photo magnets as a game for your infant or toddler. Place the magnets on a low appliance or safe piece of metal. Allow the child to arrange the pictures at their level. Add magnetic letters and numbers to increase the educational content of the activity. Family Polaroid Magnets Crop your photos so that they are square. You will be fashioning regular photographs to look like Polaroids, so you can use any digital photographs that you own. Photographs from the application Instagram are already in a square form and can be printed as is. Print off the square photographs on your printer, using photo paper. You can also print them inexpensively at a kiosk or using an online picture printing service. Aim for the photo to be approximately 3 inches by 3 inches (7.6 by 7.6 cm) - approximately the size of a standard Polaroid photo image. You can also cut them down to this size after they are printed. Buy magnet sheets at a craft store or online. Look for neodymium magnet paper. This type of magnet may be more expensive than standard magnet craft sheets; however, it can hold up considerably more weight than standard models. Cut the magnet sheets into sizes of 3.5 inches (8.9 cm) wide and 4.5 inches (11.4 cm) tall. This is approximately the size of a single Polaroid  sheet, including white space. Place double stick tape on the back of your photo in 2 to 4 places. Make sure not to touch the tape too much before application, or it will lose its stickiness. Place the photograph approximately 1/4 inch from the top and sides of the front of the magnet sheet. Press on the photograph to firmly attach it to the magnet sheet. You will leave extra space at the bottom for writing. If you are worried about aligning the photo correctly onto the magnet paper, practice before you affix the double stick tape. Trace around the top corners with the pencil. Align the corners again once you have tape on the back. Write information about your family members on the bottom of the photo magnet. You can use different colored markers for more lively illustrations. Place the magnets on a metallic surface. Glass Family Photo Magnets Purchase glass shapes and button magnets from a craft store. You will also need strong glue that dries clearly. Find photographs of your family member's profiles or faces, approximately in the size of the glass craft gems. Most gems are round, which works well with faces. Square gems will also work. Print out photographs of your family members on plain white paper. Adjust your printer's settings for a high quality printing. Cut out the faces on the photographs, so that the image is slightly bigger than the gem. It will need to wrap around the back slightly. Paint a coat of glue on the back of the glass gem. This is usually the side that is flat and less shiny. Place the photograph face forward on top of the glue. Press it down firmly with your hand. Allow it to dry. Trim any excess paper before counting. Paint a second coat of clear glue over the back of the photograph. This will firmly affix the edges of the paper, and it will make the magnet last longer. Allow the coat to dry according to package directions. Place a dot of glue on the center of the gem. Press a button magnet to the middle of the back of the photograph and gem. Allow it to dry, repeat with other photographs and place on a metal surface.
